subject: Re: How to use Jerome font?
msgSnippet: We also have a nice graphic representation (pdf format) of the Jerome keyboard in our files section:  Files/Fonts/Keybd_read.pdf Jeff
messageBody:
We also have a nice graphic representation (pdf format) of the Jerome
keyboard in our files section: Files/Fonts/Keybd_read.pdf

Jeff

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, oliver langan
<oliverlangan@y...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> Using the Jerome font is semi-intuitive, but when it isn't you will
> have to hunt around. Many letters in Jerome correspond directly to
> their standard latin equivalents, so that k = k, p = p, etc. But since
> Quickscript has many more vowel characters, for example, you will have
> to hunt around for the correct character sometimes.
>
> I suggest opening a text editor or word processor and typing out each
> character from the keyboard, like so:
> q w e r t y u i o p [ ] \
> and then copying and pasting it on the next line, in Jerome. When
> printed, it will allow you to see at a glance which characters match
> up, for easy reference.
>
> Once you have used the font for a while, and gotten accustomed to
> reading QS, it will go more quickly. That doesn't mean that there
> might not be a better way to type Quickscript.
>
> oliver
>
> On 08 Nov 2004, at 20:57, lyleraymond wrote:
> > Is there a FAQ or manual with instructions for dummies on using the
> > Jerome font? Or shall I just rely on trial and error?
